\text{Using trignometric identity,}\\ \begin{align} \sin x \cos y &= \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin (x+y) + \sin (x-y)] \\ \implies \sin 3x \cos 4x &= \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin 7x - \sin x]\\
\therefore \int \sin 3x \cos 4x dx &= \int \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin 7x - \sin x] dx \end{align}

\text{Using trignometric identity,}\\ \begin{align} \sin x \cos y &= \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin (x+y) + \sin (x-y)] \\ \implies \sin 3x \cos 4x &= \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin 7x + \sin x]\\
\therefore \int \sin 3x \cos 4x dx &= \int \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin 7x + \sin x]dx \end{align}
